BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs are prone to triggering in all aspects. Caution is to be exercised in particular above approximately 2200 m, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Avalanches can be released easily and reach medium size. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack can indicate the danger.

There is a danger of gliding avalanches and moist snow slides. This applies on steep slopes below approximately 2400 m.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep slopes above approximately 2200 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1000 m. The wind will be strong over a wide area, in particular on the Main Alpine Ridge. As a consequence of new snow and wind from northwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form. More recent wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering in particular on steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes. Gradual decrease in danger of gliding avalanches and wet snow slides as the temperature drops.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are not ruled out, in particular in case of releases originating from steep starting zones above approximately 2500 m. In the last few days sometimes easily released wind slabs formed at elevated altitudes. Single backcountry tourers can release avalanches, including medium-sized ones. In some places avalanches can also penetrate down to the ground and reach large size in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
The current avalanche situation calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 2300 m. The sleet gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack below approximately 2200 m. As a consequence of falling temperatures a crust will form on the surface. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger, especially at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes deep wind slabs formed at elevated altitudes. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to east to south facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
Gradual decrease in danger of moist avalanches as the temperature drops.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 2500 m. The sleet gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of falling temperatures a crust will form on the surface. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in high Alpine regions. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, wind slabs formed at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep north, east and southeast facing slopes. In particular in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Gradual decrease in danger of moist and wet avalanches as the temperature drops.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 2300 m. The sleet gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of falling temperatures a crust will form on the surface. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The soft wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on near-ridge shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence especially on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes. Below approximately 2000 m small moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular on steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In the regions where the wind is stronger danger level 3 (considerable) will be reached.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Until Saturday the wind will be strong adjacent to ridgelines over a wide area. The wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well. As a consequence of a gathering strong wind from northwesterly directions, large surface-area wind slabs will form especially adjacent to ridgelines as well as above the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on wind-loaded slopes of all aspects above approximately 2000 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2000 m.
The sometimes storm force wind will transport the new snow significantly. The older wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be strong to storm force at times over a wide area. In particular adjacent to ridgelines the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. On wind-loaded slopes a considerable avalanche danger will prevail.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2000 m.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, soft wind slabs formed above approximately 2400 m.
The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep north, east and south facing slopes. At high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
At high altitude small and medium-sized dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of the moderate northwesterly wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow has fallen since Monday above approximately 2500 m.
The rain gave rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2400 m. And a rapid settlement of the snowpack below about 2200 m
As a consequence of falling temperatures a crust formed on the surface.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2000 m, in particular along the border with France.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed above approximately 2300 m.
The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep north, east and south facing slopes. At elevated altitudes these avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
Above 2700 m where it has not rained the old snowdrifts have been covered by the latest snowfall.
In particular at high altitude more medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of the moderate northwesterly wind.
At low altitude only isolated small wet and gliding avalanches are possible.
Meticulous route selection is recommended.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area there is more snow than usual, in particular above approximately 2200 m.
40 to 70 cm of snow has fallen since Monday above approximately 2500 m.
The rain gave rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2400 m. And a rapid settlement of the snowpack below about 2200 m
As a consequence of falling temperatures a crust will form on the surface.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The clearly visible wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, wind slabs formed at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on northeast to southeast to south facing aspects. In particular in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow has fallen since Monday above approximately 2500 m.
In all altitude zones only a little snow is now lying. The snowpack is largely stable. The rain gave rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2400 m. And the total melting of snow below about 2200-2000 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution, especially along the border with France.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can still be released in some cases especially on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2700 m. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are to be avoided in particular in very steep terrain.
In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls. As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural avalanche activity will decrease.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying. Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Towards its base, the snowpack is moist. The sleet gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of falling temperatures a crust will form on the surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are prone to triggering above approximately 2200 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized and can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in very isolated cases in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m, especially in the north. Avalanches can reach medium size.

On steep slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. As a consequence of new snow and a light to moderate wind from variable directions, wind slabs formed in all aspects. Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. The weather conditions will foster a gradual settling of the snow drift accumulations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, easily released wind slabs formed in the last few days in particular adjacent to ridgelines as well as above the tree line. Below approximately 2000 m small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized wet avalanches are possible.
Some fresh snow and the wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are prone to triggering above approximately 2200 m. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized and can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in some places even by individual winter sport participants especially at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies in particular on very steep northwest, north and northeast facing slopes in particular above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong northerly wind, further wind slabs will form on Thursday in all aspects. Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m. Weak layers in the old snowpack are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be moderate to strong over a wide area. On Friday sometimes easily released wind slabs will form especially in the regions exposed to the foehn wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Thus far only isolated small avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in gullies and bowls above approximately 1800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: At low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations in high Alpine regions. A little new snow above approximately 1500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form especially adjacent to ridgelines as well as above the tree line. The fresh wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

The fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and at elevated altitudes. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling here.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be moist below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow is lying on top of a weakly bonded old snowpack in all aspects below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack is moist; its surface consists of loosely bonded snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
Gliding avalanches are possible in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some regions 5 to 15 cm of snow, but less in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be strong at times over a wide area. On Friday further wind slabs will form especially in the regions exposed to the foehn wind.
